content.description:
This is the standard route up Bell Mountain. Many options exist for ascending this easy but sustained third class scramble up the west face.

8 miles round trip.
content.location: Use the western approach. Hike up the boulder field until you reach the ridge, ultimately arriving at the summit block. The line is rather obvious. Don't be overly concerned about finding the "correct" path since it's all pretty much equal in terms of distance and difficulty.

content.description:
Steeper, more exposed, and more sustained than the west face is the route up the southwest gully. It's only fourth class, but there's a lot of loose and dirty rock--it is a gully, after all.

I've only descended this route, so that might be biasing my opinion of it. Overall, though, I'd say the west face or the south face are more enjoyable objectives.
content.location: Long, obvious gully just right of the prominent ridgeline that you ascend as you make your way to the summit block.

content.description:
Steepest line straight up the south face. Protection is available, but if you're experienced enough to safely protect this line--rarely, if ever climbed=mostly loose rock--you're probably better off sans rope.

Given the nature of the rock, I can't say that I recommend this face as a roped climb. As a solo/steep scramble, it's great fun!

Line is mostly 4th class to 5.0 with occasional moves up to 5.3. Definitely not sustained 5.3.

Descend via southwest gully or west face, depending on your preference.
content.protection: No protection necessary. One could, if desired, protect with traditional gear.
content.location: Same approach as West face. Once you reach the summit block, go right. Pass the obvious southwest gully and pick a line up the steepest portion.
